answers.explanation:
Values in ‘red’ represent the bottom 1% of the normal distribution of an age-matched patient’s RNFL thickness. ONH/RNFL shows reduced inferior and superior RNFL thickness as seen on this patient’s TSNIT plot (blue arrow). These findings correspond with infero-temporal and supero-temporal ganglion cell loss seen on the GCC macular cube. Poor RNFL symmetry is noted. A high cup to disc ratio in the right eye (vertical > average), interpreted by the OCT, is also seen.

![](/content/media/glaucoma-4-3.webp)

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: Based on the patient’s OCT images, what visual field defect would you expect to see?

answers.answerText: D. Nasal step with superior arcuate defect
answers.explanation:
The nasal RNFL is preserved and thus a temporal wedge would not be seen. A paracentral scotoma is indicative of severe glaucoma, which is unlikely based on the patient’s OCT results. An inferior arcuate defect is possible, however in glaucoma, RNFL loss typically begins inferiorly which would result in a nasal step or superior arcuate defect (if more advanced).

This patient’s OCT shows reduced inferior and superior RNFL thickness, which would correspond to superior and inferior visual field loss, respectively. Because inferior RNFL loss is more pronounced, one may expect to see a nasal step or superior arcuate defect. A nasal step, possibly progressing into a superior arcuate defect, is visible on the patient’s visual field grey scale (red circle).

![](/content/media/glaucoma-4-4.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What stage glaucoma does the patient have in the right eye?

answers.explanation:
The Hoddap –Parrish –Anderson (HAP) criteria is commonly used to assess glaucoma severity using the mean deviation (MD) index obtained from visual field testing. The HAP criteria defines early glaucoma as MD less than -6dB, moderate glaucoma as MD between -6dB and -12dB, and severe glaucoma as MD worse than -12dB. The MD values of this patient’s visual fields (yellow box) lie in the ‘moderate’ severity group. Central fixation is also used to determine stage. This patient’s MD value fell within the ‘moderate’ severity but visual fields showed some central involvement on the Pattern Deviation map (red arrows). Therefore, they are automatically classified as severe/advanced and will treated more aggressively.

References

1. Hodapp E, Parrish II R, Anderson D. Clinical Decisions in Glaucoma. St. Louis: Mosby-Year Book, Inc.; 1993.
